name: maize grain production, rainfed | maize grain | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20514/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of grain maize (fresh matter) in South Africa. The yield is 3770 kg/ha at a moisture content at storage of 13%.;;;Modelling is based on three different grain maize varieties, one GM-free and two GM varieties(Bazillus thuringiensis (GM-Bt) and Roundup Ready (GM-RR)), each accounting for the following proportion of total production:  ;GM-free:16.3% ;GM-Bt: 59.8% ;GM-RR: 24.0%;;;Mineral N-P2O5-K2O fertiliser input is 66-11-7  kg/ha. Organic fertilisers applied amount to 2.5  t/ha of solid manure. ;

This activity starts after the harvest of the previous crop. 

The inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers, and pesticides are considered. Manure is the only organic fertiliser applied. The dataset includes all machine operations: soil cultivation, transport of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides to the field, sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvesting, transport from field to farm (5 km). Direct field emissions are also included.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for South Africa.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The planning models apply to cultivation in three maize production regions: the Eastern Highveld, North West, and Central and Northern Free State. These data are assumed to be representative for all South African grain maize production.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Production data are from Grain SA planning models and maize production reports and from the Griekwaland Wes Korporatief (GWK) cost guide (Grain SA Operational planning of white maize grain production in the production year 2011/2012 in Eastern Highveld, South Africa; Lynnwood Ridge, South Africa, 2014; Grain SA Operational planning of white maize grain production in the production year 2011/2012 in Northwest, South Africa; Lynnwood Ridge, South Africa, 2014; Grain SA Operational planning of white maize grain production in the production year 2011/2012 in Central and Northern Free State, South Africa; Lynnwood Ridge, South Africa, 2014; Grain SA Maize production in South Africa from 2006-2013; Lynnwood Ridge, South Africa, 2014;  Rechtus, S. GWK cost guide data 2016). Transport distances were obtained from J. Coetzee, an extension officer for South African Breweries Ltd., as well as by using online distance calculators for land ( DistanceFromTo Available online: http://www.distancefromto.net (accessed on Apr 15, 2015)) and sea (SeaRates.com Available online: http://www.searates.com/de/reference/portdistance (accessed on Apr 15, 2015).) routes.

exchanges.description: Grain maize production, South African production, non-irrigated

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of pesticides needed for the production of maize grain is calculated to be circa 1.04E-03 kg. Pesticide/s used in this dataset is/are: 'atrazine', 'cyclic N-compound', 'glyphosate', 'metolachlor', 'nitrile-compound', 'pesticide, unspecified', 'phenoxy-compound', 'pyrethroid-compound', 'triazine-compound, unspecified'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of pesticide/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 2.08E-03 kg of packaging for pesticides is justified with this exchange.

Calculated value: emissions arising from fertiliser use, calculated according to Nemecek und Schnetzer (2011). Soil erosion according to Kooman & Critchley; Le Roux at al. (2008); UWC (2015), P content in topsoil according to Nemecek, Kägi T. & Blaser S. (2007), enrichment factor for P according to Wilke & Schaub (1996), fraction of eroded soil that reaches river according to Nemecek, Kägi & Blaser (2007).  
Further references: Kooman, G.; Critchley, W. R. S. GIS-Assisted Modelling of Soil Erosion in a South African Catchment: Evaluating the USLE and SLEMSA Approach. In Water Resources Planning, Development and Management; Breetzke, G. D., Ed.; InTech, 2013 ISBN 978-953-51-1092-7; Le Roux, J. J.; Morgenthal, T. L.; Malherbe, J.; Pretorius, D. J.; Sumner, P. D. Water erosion prediction at a national scale for South Africa. Water SA 2008, 34, 305-314; UWC Erosion Available online: http://www.botany.uwc.ac.za/envfacts/facts/erosion.htm (accessed on Apr 28, 2015); Nemecek, T., Kagi, T., & Blaser, S. (2007). Life Cycle Inventories of Swiss and European Agricultural Production Systems. Final report; Wilke B. & Schaub D. (1996) Phosphatanreicherung bei Bodenerosion. Mitt. Deutsche Bodenkundl. Gesellsch. 79, 435-438.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value: calculated according to Nemecek und Schnetzer (2011). Heavy metal content of inorganic fertilisers according to Desaules & Struder (1993), heavy-metal contents of organic fertilisers according to Freiermuth (2006) from Menzi & Kessler (1998) and Desaules & Studer (1993), dry matter content from Walther et al. (2001), heavy metal content of plant material and deposition according to Freiermuth (2006), leaching rates according to Wolfensberger & Dinkel (1997),  heavy metal content of the soil according to Keller & Desaules (2001), soil erosion according to Kooman & Critchley; Le Roux at al. (2008); UWC (2015), accumulation factor according to Wilke & Schaub (1986), erosion factor: 0.05, since surface waters between agricultural fields are rare and the distance to the next river or lake is greater than 100 m. Source: Freiermuth (2006). 
Further references:  Desaules A. & Studer K. (1993) NABO: Nationales Beobachtungsnetz, Messresultate 1985-1991, Schriftenreihe Umwelt Nr. 200, BUWAL (Bundesamt für Umwelt, Wald und Landschaft), Bern; Menzi H. & Kessler J.
